children.text: [Template] How much is Apple worth? Breaking down a DCF model.
Apple is one of the most valuable companies in the world with a current market cap of
Apple is valued or whether its current market price is overvalued or undervalued?
One approach to valuing a company like Apple is to use a discounted cash flow model (DCF), which takes into account the company's future cash flows to estimate it's current value.

This interactive model breaks down how to build a DCF model for Apple and estimate an intrinsic value per share. We can then compare that to Apple's actual share price. Intrinsic value is our model's estimate of the fair value of a company; not actual market conditions.
. This is a template for building a DCF model.
. You can duplicate this model to reuse it or modify it to your own assumptions.
This model is broken down into five areas:
Forecasting Apple's Future Free Cash Flows
. I use historical data to make assumptions about the future. I assume
. But, you can explore different scenarios around growth.
: By calculating a terminal value, we can capture a more complete picture of Apple's overall value. Here I use the perpetuity approach.
: Discounting Apple's future free cash to the present using a
discount rate in-line with the 10 Year Treasury
Calculating Apple's theoretical enterprise value and market value based on our assumptions to estimate a value per share.
Comparing our model's intrinsic value per share to Apple's actual share price and exploring scenarios around our

My first step in constructing this model is to estimate Apple's future cash flows. There are many ways to do this, but one approach is to use historical financials to make assumptions about a company's future revenue growth, margins, and capital expenditures.
I am going to look back 5 years for Apple. You may want to look back 10 years to capture a broader cycle.
I am going to make some general assumptions to forecast future free cash. When looking at key drivers of future free cash such as
and my own assumptions on the market,
I am going to assume no expansion in Apple's future free cash. That free cash will maintain it's post 2020 highs.
To represent this, I will use an average of Apple's free cash flow and EBITDA from the last two years as the future free cash (FFC) and future EBITDA.

I am going to project out this assumption for 5 years as Apple is a fairly steady state business. Since I am assuming no growth in free cash, the forecast for EBITDA and FCF is the same YoY.  At the end of this model, you can explore what would happen if free cash grew or contracted.
represents the estimated value of a company beyond the final year of the explicit forecast period. It creates a more complete picture of a company's value.
There are different ways to calculate TV, but one common approach is to assume that a company's FCF will stay constant beyond the projection period â€”
In this model, TV is the present value of future cash flows in perpetuity. We can estimate TV by using our future free cash flow estimate and dividing by a discount rate. I am going to assume a
close to the ten year treasury rate:

Now, we can discount Apple's projected FCF and TV to their present values using the discount rate. This accounts for the fact that money in the future is worth less than money in the present. We're assuming a
We can calculate this using the
which will calculate the present value of our five year forecasted future cash flows.
We also have to discount Apple's terminal value to present value. TV is in perpetuity beyond our initial forecast. Using the net present value function, it will be 0 for the first 4 years.
Now that we have the present value of FCF and TV, we can compute Apple's enterprise value:

Finally, let's calculate Apple's value per share based on our assumptions about the future:
